articles.headline: I.B.M. Names Virginia Rometty as New Chief Executive
articles.snippet: The selection of Ms. Rometty, a senior vice president at I.B.M., will make her one of the highest-profile women executives in corporate America.
articles.abstract: The selection of Ms. Rometty, a senior vice president at I.B.M., will make her one of the highest-profile women executives in corporate America.
articles.lead_paragraph: Virginia M. Rometty, a senior vice president at I.B.M., will be the company’s next chief executive, the directors announced on Tuesday. She will succeed Samuel J. Palmisano, 60, who will remain as chairman, at the start of next year.

articles.headline: Amazon Suffers Big Drop in Income
articles.snippet: The online retailer had a 44 percent increase in revenue, but investors still fled the stock in after-hours trading.
articles.abstract: The online retailer had a 44 percent increase in revenue, but investors still fled the stock in after-hours trading.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors shrugged off Amazon’s warnings this summer that its third quarter would be weak.

articles.headline: New Poll Finds a Deep Distrust of Government
articles.snippet: With Election Day just over a year away, a deep sense of economic anxiety and doubt about the future hangs over the nation.
articles.abstract: With Election Day just over a year away, a deep sense of economic anxiety and doubt about the future hangs over the nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: With Election Day just over a year away, a deep sense of economic anxiety and doubt about the future hangs over the nation, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, with Americans’ distrust of government at its highest level ever.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Megan Thee-Brenan

articles.headline: New Technologies Redraw the World’s Energy Picture
articles.snippet: Unconventional fossil fuels extracted by new technologies should shift geopolitical and economic calculations around the world in the coming decades.
articles.abstract: Unconventional fossil fuels extracted by new technologies should shift geopolitical and economic calculations around the world in the coming decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: GOLDA MEIR, the former prime minister of Israel, used to tell a joke about how Moses must have made a wrong turn in the desert: “He dragged us 40 years through the desert to bring us to the one place in the Middle East where there was no oil.’ ”

articles.headline: China Takes a Loss to Get Ahead in the Business of Fresh Water
articles.snippet: The Chinese government hopes to become a force in yet another environment-related industry: supplying the world with desalinated water.
articles.abstract: The Chinese government hopes to become a force in yet another environment-related industry: supplying the world with desalinated water.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIANJIN, China — Towering over the Bohai Sea shoreline on this city’s outskirts, the Beijiang Power and Desalination Plant is a 26-billion-renminbi technical marvel: an ultrahigh-temperature, coal-fired generator with state-of-the-art pollution controls, mated to advanced Israeli equipment that uses its leftover heat to distill seawater into fresh water.

articles.headline: Telemundo Blends English Into a Mostly Spanish Lineup
articles.snippet: The network is planning to show English-language subtitles in an effort to attract viewers among the skyrocketing number of second- and third-generation Hispanic-Americans.
articles.abstract: The network is planning to show English-language subtitles in an effort to attract viewers among the skyrocketing number of second- and third-generation Hispanic-Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Telemundo has long trailed its rival Univision in their competition for Hispanic television viewers in the United States. But as the number of second- and third-generation Hispanic-Americans skyrockets, the perennial runner-up is embracing a new strategy — English-language subtitles and Spanglish — to attract deep-pocketed viewers and the advertisers who covet them.

articles.headline: Venture Capitalists Put Money on Easing Medical Device Rules
articles.snippet: As Congress considers reauthorizing a law that sets the fees for medical device makers, venture capitalists are emerging as an influential ally of companies eager for a quicker regulatory process.
articles.abstract: As Congress considers reauthorizing a law that sets the fees for medical device makers, venture capitalists are emerging as an influential ally of companies eager for a quicker regulatory process.
articles.lead_paragraph: One afternoon last spring, a little-known congressman from Minnesota made an impassioned plea before a House oversight committee.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and Janet Roberts

articles.headline: At Olympus, Western Questions for Old-School Ways
articles.snippet: The Japanese firm Olympus said its president and chairman Tsuyoshi Kikukawa had stepped down after the company became embroiled in a scandal over a series of costly acquisitions.
articles.abstract: The Japanese firm Olympus said its president and chairman Tsuyoshi Kikukawa had stepped down after the company became embroiled in a scandal over a series of costly acquisitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO —  One was a rising star at Olympus, a Briton who shocked his colleagues by leapfrogging scores of executives to become the company’s first non-Japanese president.

articles.headline: Europe Agrees to Basics of Plan to Resolve Euro Crisis
articles.snippet: European leaders made significant progress in resolving the euro zone financial crisis, obtaining an agreement from banks to take a 50 percent loss on the value of their Greek debt.
articles.abstract: European leaders made significant progress in resolving the euro zone financial crisis, obtaining an agreement from banks to take a 50 percent loss on the value of their Greek debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European leaders, in a significant step toward resolving the euro zone financial crisis, early Thursday morning obtained an agreement from banks to take a 50 percent loss on the face value of their Greek debt.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Stephen Castle
